head.title: China and Taiwan Are Warming to Each Other

hedline.hl1: China and Taiwan Are Warming to Each Other

abstract.p: Amar Hamoudi letter says that, contrary to Pres Clinton's recent statement, China's total carbon dioxide emissions are unlikely to overtake those of US for another ten to twenty years (S)

block.p: In Shanghai President Clinton warned that China was about to assume the distinction of replacing the United States as the largest emitter of greenhouse gases (news article, June 25).
In Shanghai President Clinton warned that China was about to assume the distinction of replacing the United States as the largest emitter of greenhouse gases (news article, June 25).

Data from the Carbon Dioxide Information Analysis Center suggest that the President's comments are premature. China's total carbon dioxide emissions are unlikely to overtake the United States for another 10 to 20 years, and in per-capita terms China's carbon dioxide emissions are still one-sixth of those of the United States.

It is true that the developing world has begun to claim an increasing share of the world's greenhouse emissions. Ultimately, however, policies informed by an understanding of the relationships between technology, economic growth and emissions will prove more helpful than alarmist rhetoric in addressing these trends.
The writer is with Harvard's Institute for International Development.
